title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not correctly identify the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound L – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

The response correctly identifies the intermolecular forces in both compounds.

· Compound L – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

· Compound X – dispersion forces, dipole-dipole forces, and hydrogen bonding

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· Although both compounds have the same types of intermolecular forces, the boiling point data indicate that the total of all intermolecular forces is greater in compound X than in compound L. The London dispersion forces in compound L and compound X are comparable due to their similar number of atoms, but compound X has a greater number of hydrogen bonding sites than compound L. Therefore, compound X has the higher boiling point.

The response provides a correct explanation equivalent to the following.

· Although both compounds have the same types of intermolecular forces, the boiling point data indicate that the total of all intermolecular forces is greater in compound X than in compound L. The London dispersion forces in compound L and compound X are comparable due to their similar number of atoms, but compound X has a greater number of hydrogen bonding sites than compound L. Therefore, compound X has the higher boiling point.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification equivalent to one of the following.

· No. If the second step of the mechanism is rate-determining, the second peak in the diagram should show a higher activation energy, not a lower activation energy, than the first step.

OR

· No. The higher energy of the products relative to the reactants is consistent with an endothermic reaction, not an exothermic reaction.
